questions.text: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm).

It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis.

Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.

Related Pearl: Measurements of EAC and ET

 

External Auditory Canal

Eustachian tube

Total length

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the eustachian tube?

choices.text: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.solution:
The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity.

It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts:

  • Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12 mm in size.
  • Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is 24 mm in size.

In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the narrowest part of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is the isthmus. It is the junction of the bony and cartilaginous parts.

Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube.

questions.text: You are an intern asking a patient to perform a Valsalva manoeuvre for the relief of an ear block. Which of the following structure helps in opening the eustachian tube during this manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the Eustachian tube during the Valsalva manoeuvre.

It is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning and sneezing.

Opening of the tube

  • The medial fibres of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and contract to open the tubal lumen. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle.
  • Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatine & salpingopharyngeus

Closure of the tube

  • It is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof.

Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.

questions.text: Which of the following supplies the tensor veli palatini muscle?
questions.solution:
The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve supplies the tensor veli palatini which opens the Eustachian tube.

Muscles of the Eustachian tube:

Muscle

Nerve supply

Action

Tensor veli palatine/ Dilator tubae

Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve

Opens the tube

Levator veli palatine

Opens & lifts the tube

Salpingopharyngeus

Pharyngeal plexus 

Opens the tube

Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal Nerve

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent attacks of acute otitis media. Which of the following properties of the eustachian tube predisposes to this?
questions.solution:
The Eustachian tube in children is wider, shorter (13-18mm), and more horizontal. The cartilaginous part is flaccid due to less elastin.

The above differences make children more prone to retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and middle ear infections. In infants along with the secretions, the milk also refluxes back while feeding in the supine position.

Related Pearl: Differences between infant & adult ET

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause for functional eustachian tube obstruction?
questions.solution:
Cleft palate is a cause for functional Eustachian tube (ET) obstruction. 

Eustachian tube obstruction can be mechanical, functional or both. Mechanical obstruction can result from intrinsic causes such as inflammation or allergy or extrinsic causes such as tumour or adenoids. Functional obstruction is caused by collapse of the tube due to increased cartilage compliance or failure of active tubal opening mechanism due to poor function of tensor veli palatini. 

In the cleft palate, the obstruction is due to high elastin content at torus tubaris and the poor function of tensor veli palatini.

Related Pearl: Causes of ET Obstruction

Mechanical
Functional
Extrinsic/ block at opening Intrinsic/ edema

Cleft palate

Down’s syndrome

Neuromuscular disorders

Adenoid hypertrophy

Nasopharyngeal tumor

DNS

Sinonasal polyps

Sinusitis

URTI

Allergy

questions.text: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.solution:
Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used to detect malingering of hearing loss.

Tests of Eustachian tube patency:

  • Pneumatic otoscopy
  • Nasopharyngoscopy
  • Valsalva manoeuvre
  • ET catheterization
  • Politzer test.

Tests of Eustachian tube function:

  • Toynbee’s test
  • Tympanometry
  • Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears
  • Sonotubometry.

questions.text: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in the nasopharynx and not negative pressure.

In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positive pressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by the tympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy.

It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear.

It is contraindicated in:

  • Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured.
  • URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Valsalva vs. Toynbee

 

Valsalva

Toynbee

Maneuver

Blow with closed nose & mouth

Swallow with closed nose & mouth

Pressure build-up in the nasopharynx

Positive

Negative

Test of

ET patency

ET function

Result on TM

TM moves out

TM moves inwards/ retracts

Contraindications

Atrophic TM

Acute infections in the nose and pharynx

Atrophic TM

questions.text: An otolaryngologist is performing the following procedure in a patient. Which of the following is true about this procedure?

choices.text: Used to instill medications into middle ear

questions.solution:
The procedure depicted in the image is Eustachian tube (ET) catheterization and it uses Politzer’s bag and an ET catheter.

The catheter is passed along the nasal floor and manoeuvred into the ET opening and the bag is insufflated. The outward movement of the tympanic membrane is then noted with an otoscope.

It is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, scarring of ET, epistaxis, spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear.

In the methylene blue dye test, the dye is instilled into the middle ear and the time taken by it to stain the pharynx is noted.

Politzer test is a non-invasive alternative for this and works on the same principle. It uses a nasal olive instead of a catheter and is useful in children who can’t perform the Valsalva or Toynbee test.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after an episode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tube defect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is an objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation.

In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. The disadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

 

Related Pearl: Valsalva vs. Toynbee

 

Valsalva

Toynbee

Blow with closed nose & mouth

questions.text: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube.

Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds. 

Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple sclerosis.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no ear fullness.

Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing their own voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachian tube.

Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony.

questions.text: For a patient to get barotraumatic otitis media, what is the critical level of the atmospheric pressure required?
questions.solution:
The critical level of the atmospheric pressure required to cause barotraumatic otitis media is 90 mm Hg. 

At this point, the atmospheric pressure is higher than the middle ear and it causes the eustachian tube blockage.

questions.text: Which of the following activities is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma?
questions.solution:
A pilot performing take-off (i.e. rapid ascent in the air) is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma compared to other options.

The usual causes for otitic barotrauma are

  • Rapid descent during air travel (skydiver)
  • Underwater diving (scuba diving)
  • Compression in a pressure chamber (hyperbaric oxygen therapy).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of otitic barotrauma?
questions.solution:
Hyperacusis is not a feature of otitic barotrauma.

Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. It is usually caused by rapid descent during air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber.

  • Severe earache, deafness, and tinnitus are common complaints.
  • The TM appears retracted and congested. It can get ruptured in severe cases.
  • The middle ear may show air bubbles or hemorrhagic effusion.
  • Hearing loss is usually conductive.
  • Rarely, there is a rupture of labyrinthine membranes causing vertigo and sensorineural hearing loss.
